phrase.content: I am a doctor. I do not speak your language. I will communicate with you using this website. Answer me in English as much as possible. Thank you.
What's your name?
Please give me your Identity Card or Work Permit
Which company are you employed under / work for?
What is your supervisor‚Äôs name and contact number?
Where do you live in Singapore?
Do you know if any infected patients are from your area?
In the last 14 days, did you meet anyone who has coronavirus?
How many people are staying in the same room as you?
Who? What is your relationship with them?
How many days ago did you meet them?
How long were you with him/her?
In the last 14 days, did you travel out of Singapore? If yes, tell us the countries in English.
What were your activities for last 7 days before onset of symptoms?
What were your activities until admission?
We need the contacts of people who they were close to.
Where have you visited recently? (or maybe nowhere after circuit breaker)
Where do you buy food?
Do you have a fever?
How many days?
Did you measure it with a thermometer? If you did, what was the highest reading?
Runny nose?
Cough?
Sore throat?
Difficulty breathing?
Cannot smell properly?
Do you feel less taste in the mouth?
Do you have diarrhoea / diarrhea? How many times a day?
Skin Rash or Itching?
Do you have any pain on your body?
Specifically, any chest pain?
Point to the place.
Do you have any past medical history?
Point to which ones.
Asthma
Pneumonia
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia / Cholesterol
Diabetes
Heart problems
Kidney problems
Do you have a drug allergy?
Do you smoke? If yes, how many cigarettes a day?
Do you drink? If yes, how much (number of bottles a week, type of alcohol)?
How do you feel emotionally?
Do you have suicidal thoughts?
If you have any other problems, you can tell me in English.
I‚Äôm going to examine you.
Tell me if you feel more pain.
Please remove your shirt.
Keep taking deep breaths through your mouth.
Say "99" when I listen with my stethoscope.
I'm going to put this cotton bud into your nostrils. You will feel strange but it is not painful.
If coronavirus positive, we call your phone by tomorrow.
This is to test for coronavirus
If coronavirus negative, we send you an SMS after 3 days.
Tilt your head back
Later, you will do an X-ray
There is no sign of infection on your X-ray
If your COVID Swab is negative but you have symptoms of fever, cough, runny nose, you have to remain in an isolation area.
You can go back soon.
Wait here, do not leave this area
You have to stay in the hospital for a few days
I'll give you medicine to make you feel better
You must come back if you have problems with breathing.
You must not work for the next 5 days.
You must come back if you do not recover completely after 5 days.
Read the handout carefully
Thank you
Please avoid public transport.
You can take your own private transport, a taxi or a private hire car.
Wear a mask and sit alone in the back seat in the car.
Open car windows and turn off air-conditioning.
Please safely keep the receipt from the taxi or private hire car. If your test results indicate you are infected, this will be needed.
Stay away from others. You must stay home and can not go outside while being on medical leave. You may only go out for health or medical reasons.

If you need to go for any medical appointment before you get your test result, be careful. Tell the doctor, nurse, or other staff that you were recently tested for COVID-19. Also, tell them about your symptoms. Before the day, you should call 6344 8222 to inform them.
You have tested positive for coronavirus.
We will take you to the hospital.
We will transfer you to an isolation facility.
Good morning
Good Evening
Good Afternoon
I am the nurse
I am the doctor
You are in the intensive care unit.
Today is Monday
Today is Tuesday
Today is Wednesday
Today is Thursday
Today is Friday
Today is Saturday
Today is Sunday
You are getting better
We will remove the breathing tube when you are better
You can talk after we remove the breathing tube
Take a deep breath
Give me a big cough
Don‚Äôt struggle
Don‚Äôt move
Lift up your arm
Lift up your leg
Squeeze my hand
Show me two fingers
Open your mouth
Stick out your tongue
Open your eyes
I‚Äôm going to shine a light into your eyes. It will be bright.
phrase.summary: Shine a light into your eyes

phrase.content: Your lungs are weak. We are going to insert a breathing tube to help you breathe
You are going to sleep now
We are turning you onto your belly to help your lungs expand
We are inserting a tube to help you pass urine
We are inserting a tube through your nose
We are going to give you an injection in your neck to give you medications
We are going to give you an injection in your arm to measure your blood pressure
We will give you sleeping medications.
We will give you painkillers.
We are giving you medication to keep your blood pressure up.
We are going to remove the breathing tube.
We are going to suck out your phlegm
We are going to clean you with a sponge
Turn left
Turn right
We will change your diapers
Lift up your leg
We are going to sit you up
phrase.summary: We are going to sit you up

phrase.content: We are going to shift you up the bed
We are going to clean your mouth
Do not swallow the gargle
Are you in pain?
Where is the pain?
Is it mild, moderate or severe?
phrase.summary: Is it mild, moderate or severe?

phrase.content: Can you point to the pain?
phrase.summary: Can you point to the pain?

Stay in a separate room at home. It is best if the room has an attached bathroom. This is to reduce contact with the other members of the house. If you are using a shared bathroom, the bathroom needs to be cleaned before or after you use it.
Arrange for food, water, and other supplies to be placed outside your room. You yourself have to bring those items into your room.
Until you know your swab test results, reduce your contact with family members. Especially, try not to get near older people.
Please maintain good personal hygiene. Wash your hands with soap and water frequently. Try not to touch your eyes, nose, and mouth. Always cover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.
Please prevent others from using your spoon, fork, plates, bowls, food. Also do not share personal hygiene items like your towel.
Continue to take the medications prescribed for you (if any).
Please drink a lot of water.
Keep monitoring your temperature and symptoms at home.
Please avoid public transport.
You can take your own private transport, a taxi or a private hire car.
If your cough is getting worse and you feel breathless, or your fever is persistently above 38 degrees Celsius
Wear a surgical mask and come to our Emergency Department.
In an emergency situation, call 995 for an ambulance. Inform the ambulance operator that you were recently tested for COVID-19 and also tell them your travel history.
1) Connect the blood pressure cuff to the reader machine.
2) The ‚Äúarrow‚Äù on the the cuff should be pointing downwards on the inside of your arm.
(!) The cuff should be positioned 1 to 2 cm above your elbow joint.
3) The BP cuff should fit snugly onto your arm. It should not feel loose. Leave some space enough for 1 left finger to fit in (for good gauge)
4) Do not bend the tube during blood pressure measurement.
5) Relax & Rest your entire arm on a table while measuring your blood pressure.
6) Press the ‚ÄúStart/Stop‚Äù button to start measuring your BP. Wait for 1 minute until 3 numbers appear.
7) The top number is your Systolic blood pressure. The middle number is your Diastolic blood pressure. The bottom number is your Pulse rate.

What is COVID-19?

COVID-19 (more specifically, a coronavirus) is an illness that started from the Wuhan City in China, it is a respiratory illness.

What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

The most common symptoms are fever, tiredness and dry cough. Some patients also have a runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea. These symptoms are usually mild.

Some people become infected but do not have any symptoms.

However, it also can be caused by a lung infection or pneumonia.
phrase.summary: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

phrase.content:
How does COVID-19 spread?

People can be infected by other persons already infected with COVID-19. The virus spreads through cough and sneezing. The virus can also spread with saliva from the mouth, used plates, spoons, and forks.

What is the test for COVID-19?

It is a swab test. A swab will be inserted in your nostrils or at the back of your throat. It will last about 10 seconds. There might be a slight discomfort, however, it is not too painful.

What if I have COVID-19?

Authority will make separate living arrangements for you or admit you to a hospital. They will monitor your health, whether it is improving or not. X-ray or blood test may also be needed. Usually, they will test your swab every 24 hours. If your test is negative twice in a row, you will be released. But after going home, you have to stay separate from everyone for 2 weeks.

Will I die if I have COVID-19?

COVID-19 may make you and your family worried. However, 80% of the time, COVID-19 infections are mild. They do not even need any treatment. There is a slight risk of damage to those who are old or have other health problems. Only 5% of patients need ICU for helping them breathe.

Is there a treatment for COVID-19?

Most patients of COVID-19 do not need any treatment. They only need medicine for cough, fever and other symptoms. However, for 5% of the patients who are very ill, there are no proven treatments. However, we are very near to discovering treatment. Do not be afraid. If you have problems breathing we will use a machine to help you breathe. We will give you medicine for blood pressure.

How much will I have to pay for Treatment?

According to the announcement of the Singapore Government, if you are a citizen of Singapore, or a permanent resident, or a long term pass holder, the government will pay. So even if you have a work permit, the government will pay. But, if you went out of Singapore after 27 March 2020 and get admitted within 14 days of returning, the government will not pay your bills.

I am worried about not working. Will I lose my job?

Your employer has to allow your treatment by the law. The employer has to pay your salary even if you cannot work now.  If your salary is not paid timely, the Singapore Government can take action against the employer.
